verses.text: Why, O LORD, do you stand far off? Why do you hide yourself in times of trouble?
In his arrogance the wicked man hunts down the weak, who are caught in the schemes he devises.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 10 This psalm has no title. In its original form, it was likely combined with Ps. 9 (see above on Ps. 9). Taken separately the psalm would be an individual lament, bemoaning the wicked who victimize the righteous and calling on God to restore justice.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10:1
rsbNotes.text: 10:1 Why . . . do you stand afar off. The psalmist is more troubled by the apparent absence of God than by the presence of enemies.

verses.text: He boasts of the cravings of his heart; he blesses the greedy and reviles the LORD.
In his pride the wicked does not seek him; in all his thoughts there is no room for God.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10:3
rsbNotes.text: 10:3 boasts . . . renounces. The wicked person’s ethical judgments are upside-down. He should bless the Lord and reject the greedy.

verses.text: His ways are always prosperous; he is haughty and your laws are far from him; he sneers at all his enemies.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10:5
rsbNotes.text: 10:5 prosper at all times. From the perspective of the oppressed, it appears that the oppressor has no troubles (Ps. 73:12).

verses.text: He says to himself, "Nothing will shake me; I'll always be happy and never have trouble."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10:6
rsbNotes.text: 10:6 I shall not be moved. This attitude of self-trust brought trouble to the psalmist himself (Ps. 30:6). Confidence must be in God, not in one’s own ability.

verses.text: His mouth is full of curses and lies and threats; trouble and evil are under his tongue.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10:7
rsbNotes.text: 10:7 mouth . . . tongue. Sins of speech are the focus of attention. Rom. 3:14 alludes to this verse.

verses.text: He lies in wait near the villages; from ambush he murders the innocent, watching in secret for his victims.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10:8
rsbNotes.text:
10:8 sits in ambush. The metaphor of the wicked in ambush is well known from Proverbs (Prov. 1:11).

stealthily. The wicked prefer to work in darkness, not in the light (John 3:19).

verses.text: He lies in wait like a lion in cover; he lies in wait to catch the helpless; he catches the helpless and drags them off in his net.
His victims are crushed, they collapse; they fall under his strength.
He says to himself, "God has forgotten; he covers his face and never sees."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10:9
rsbNotes.text: 10:9 into his net. The wicked is a hunter of the helpless.

verses.text: Arise, LORD! Lift up your hand, O God. Do not forget the helpless.
Why does the wicked man revile God? Why does he say to himself, "He won't call me to account"?

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10:12
rsbNotes.text:
10:12 Arise, O Lord. See note 3:7.

lift up your hand. The metaphor refers to God’s active intervention on behalf of the psalmist.

verses.text: But you, O God, do see trouble and grief; you consider it to take it in hand. The victim commits himself to you; you are the helper of the fatherless.
Break the arm of the wicked and evil man; call him to account for his wickedness that would not be found out.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 10:14
rsbNotes.text: 10:14 fatherless. In the ancient Near East the fatherless and the widow were extreme examples of helplessness, since they had no kinship protection.
